Why are synagogues referred to as temples and not churches?

Only Reform synagogues are called temples, never call an Orthodox synagogue that, its offensive.

The reason Reform Jews started calling their synagogues temples was part of their early radical teachings that deliberately aimed to toss out outdated beliefs. Judaism has only ever had one Temple- the Beit haMikdash in Jerusalem, which was destroyed by the Romans in 70 CE. A synagogue is absolutely NOT a Temple and, in fact, there are a number of things we pointed ly do not do in synagogues because they are reserved for the Temple.

Reform Jews wanted to get rid of all the Temple nostalgia and prayers to go back to Jerusalem and rebuild the Temple (original Reform was very anti-Zionist) and provocatively started calling their synagogues temples, which scandalised and outraged more traditional Jews.

n any case, the name stuck in the Reform movement, even though Reform Jews have reconsidered some of their earlier radicalism.

As for churches, the word church has a clear Christian association and refers not only to a building but also to an institution. None of that applies in Judaism and even Reform Jews do not want to blue the lines with Christianity.

Why aren't there churches/cathedrals named after God?

They are plenty, at least in the Orthodox Christian tradition.

The most famous church of Orthodox Christianity is none other than the Byzantine basilica of Hagia Sophia.

Hagia Sophia means Holy Wisdom in Greek, but in full it refers to the Holy Wisdom of God, a concept often associated with Christ.

Another popular church name is Hagia Triada, the Holy Trinity. Given the trinitarian nature of God as described by Nicene Christianity, churches bearing this name are literally named after God.

The Holy Trinity church in Istanbul is the largest Orthodox church currently in use there.

Yet another common n

They are plenty, at least in the Orthodox Christian tradition.

The most famous church of Orthodox Christianity is none other than the Byzantine basilica of Hagia Sophia.

Hagia Sophia means Holy Wisdom in Greek, but in full it refers to the Holy Wisdom of God, a concept often associated with Christ.

Another popular church name is Hagia Triada, the Holy Trinity. Given the trinitarian nature of God as described by Nicene Christianity, churches bearing this name are literally named after God.

The Holy Trinity church in Istanbul is the largest Orthodox church currently in use there.

Yet another common name for Orthodox churches is Hagiou Pneumatos, or church of the Holy Spirit, the third person of the trinitarian God.

Other names are church of (Christ) the Pantocrator (Greek for Almighty) and church of the Saviour/Redeemer (tou Sotiros).

Finally, there are several other more indirect names like Metamorpfosis tou Sotiros (of the Transfiguration of the Redeemer), Theophanion (of the Epiphany), Anastaseos tou Kyriou (of the Resurrection of the Lord), tis Ypapantis (of the Presentation of the Lord), tis Analipseos tou Kyriou (of the Ascension of the Lord).

Are temples and churches the same?

Not quite.

A temple is a building for worship. If it is used for Christian worship, it may be called a church, but church derived from the Greek word kyriake, meaning the Lords thing, has a dual meaning in English; it can mean the gathered Christian people, or the building in which they gather for worship.

In Greek there are two different words, naos (temple) for the building, and ekklesia (assembly, congregation) for the people. By using one word for both, English tends to confuse the two. But not all temples are used for Christian worship, so a Hindu temple, for example, is not a chu

Not quite.

A temple is a building for worship. If it is used for Christian worship, it may be called a church, but church derived from the Greek word kyriake, meaning the Lords thing, has a dual meaning in English; it can mean the gathered Christian people, or the building in which they gather for worship.

In Greek there are two different words, naos (temple) for the building, and ekklesia (assembly, congregation) for the people. By using one word for both, English tends to confuse the two. But not all temples are used for Christian worship, so a Hindu temple, for example, is not a church.

How are Christian Churches different from the temples of what is known as Hinduism?

I was born in a Christian family and hence been to churches from childhood. And since most of my friends in India were Hindus, I have also been to numerous Hindu temples with them.

I may be wrong in some observations, but here are some differences in my experience -
* Hindus generally go to temple anytime they find convenient or important. Unlike the fixed mass timings of the church.
* A 'visit' to the temple (different from 'attending' church), can last from just few minutes to as long as one pleases.
* In almost every temple, they leave the footwear outside (unlike in churches they prohibit footwear only at the altar, though because of Indian tradition some churches follow temple-like rules).
* Since Hinduism has many gods, different temples have different deities. Depending on the occasion, family God, or convenience, Hindus visit different temples.
* The priest in the temple is available for the whole day (opening hours) helping people offer prayers.
* People go to temple and may not drop money in the offering box. Compared to that in a church almost everyone present durinf the offering time feels socially pressurised to donate.
* Christians are generally 'members' of a church, paying subscription fees etc. There is generally no such membership with temples. People visit any temple they please and find convenient.
* In temples they give something called a prasad (or prasadam) which is generally cooked fresh and sweet or salty. It is generally tasty. Compared to that in churches they give wafer and wine.
* The prasadam is open to all, while in church one is expected to be 'confirmed' before receiving it.
* Church is supposed to be about fellowship, and members of a church form social bonds over time. Temples is more of individual/family matter.
* I suppose most individual temples are run independently. Unlike that, churches are generally run by much larger organisations. I attended CSI, which stands for church of south India, which employs 100s of people. The catholic church must be a million times richer and much larger.
* Architecturally temples mostly follow Indian traditions and are designed for Indian weather. Many churches (even in India) try to follow European architecture with slopes designed for snow, high ceiling, painted glass etc.
* Most temples are made with stone and are naturally cooler, while most churches have fans.
* There is lot of norms that temples follow in terms of structure, directions they face, where the deity is placed, where the pillars are, where the pond is etc (norms that are generally called as vaastu).
* In temples, people generally go around the deity a few times.
* Some larger temples serve free food.
* Many Indian Christian men dress up in European style (with suit, tie, leather shoes etc) while at church.
* EDIT (courtesy: Somdip Datta) - churches generally have benches to sit on, whereas temples have natural seating on the cool stone floor (which has a very nice feel to it).
* EDIT (courtesy news in India) - Menstruating women can't enter temples. In some temples like the famous Sabrimala, women who are even just capable of menstruation (age 10-50) cannot enter the temple. Churches don't seem to care about menstruation.

Some similarities -
* Both are about God, sacredness and prayers.
* Both run on offerings to God.
* Both mostly don't disclose their earnings or how it is spent, back to donors.
* Both don't pay taxes
* Both exercise some dress code. In one temple I visited men were supposed to be topless. Women have to cover the legs in most temples.
* Both own real estate.
* Both offer social events like festivals, carnivals etc
* Both have priests as mediator to God.
* Both have restricted area available only to the priests
* Both use some form of sounds (bells, singing, scripture recital, music etc)

Why aren't doctors called healers?

Typically, persons who call themselves healers have been practitioners of complementary medicine. Mainstream medicine involves modalities that doctors are taught in medical school and throughout training. There is some crossover as some physicians go on to learn more about complementary techniques and may use these in their practice.

I would be reluctant to ascribe healing to medical intervention and prefer to be referred to as a physician. I view healing as a process inherent to the patient that can be promoted by supportive interventions.

Originally Answered: Why aren't non jains allowed in JAIN temples?

Why arent non-Hindus allowed in temples?

First of all, the vast majority of Hindu temples allow non-Hindus to enter. There are hundreds of thousands of Hindu temples that non-Hindus would be able to visit around the world. Secondly, those few temples that do disallow non-Hindus from entering have a good reason to do so.

Non-Hindus would not maintain the same lifestyle and diet as Hindus would. Non-Hindus consume beef and do not know the proper methodology of going to a temple. This is the main reason why non-Hindus are restricted from entering the Jagannath Temple in Orissa. It is the rule of the deity in the temple that no impure per

First of all, the vast majority of Hindu temples allow non-Hindus to enter. There are hundreds of thousands of Hindu temples that non-Hindus would be able to visit around the world. Secondly, those few temples that do disallow non-Hindus from entering have a good reason to do so.

Non-Hindus would not maintain the same lifestyle and diet as Hindus would. Non-Hindus consume beef and do not know the proper methodology of going to a temple. This is the main reason why non-Hindus are restricted from entering the Jagannath Temple in Orissa. It is the rule of the deity in the temple that no impure person may enter the temple. When one does enter, locals say that it begins to rain at the temple to wash away their presence after they have gone.

However, once again, as I said, that is the rule only in some places. If you would like to go visit a temple, just google if there are any Hindu temples in your city or in nearby cities, and you will most often be welcomed there. Many Hindu temples also offer food (prasadam) to the public, anyone can enjoy free food as it is our duty to serve bhojan to people regardless of their religion, caste, ethnicity, etc.

What churches are built upon ancient temples?

There are many churches that have been built on or near the sites of ancient temples. This is often because the site holds religious significance for the particular faith, or because the site was considered to be a sacred or holy place. Some examples of churches that have been built on or near ancient temples include:

  • The Church of the Holy Sepulchre in Jerusalem, which is believed to be built on the site of the tomb of Jesus and is revered as one of the holiest places in Christianity.
  • The Temple Mount in Jerusalem, which is considered a sacred site in Judaism, Christianity, and Islam. The site is home to several important religious buildings, including the Dome of the Rock, which is a Muslim shrine, and the Western Wall, which is a Jewish holy site.
  • The Hagia Sophia in Istanbul, Turkey, which was originally a Greek Orthodox cathedral, then a mosque, and is now a museum. It was built on the site of an ancient temple dedicated to the goddess Artemis.
  • The Pantheon in Rome, Italy, which was originally a Roman temple dedicated to the gods, but was later converted into a church. It is now a museum.

There are many other examples of churches that have been built on or near ancient temples, and the specific details of these sites can vary widely

What is a person who has no religion called?

1. Atheist: The term atheist can be defined literally as lacking a humanoid god concept, but historically it means one of two things. Positive atheism asserts that a personal supreme being does not exist. Negative atheism simply asserts a lack of belief in such a deity. It is possible to be a positive atheist about the Christian God, for example, while maintaining a stance of negative atheism or even uncertainty on the question of a more abstract deity like a prime mover.

1. Atheist: The term atheist can be defined literally as lacking a humanoid god concept, but historically it means one of two things. Positive atheism asserts that a personal supreme being does not exist. Negative atheism simply asserts a lack of belief in such a deity. It is possible to be a positive atheist about the Christian God, for example, while maintaining a stance of negative atheism or even uncertainty on the question of a more abstract deity like a prime mover.

2. Anti-theist: Some people want a term that more clearly conveys their opposition to the whole religious enterprise. The term anti-theist says, I think religion is harmful. It also implies some form of activism that goes beyond merely advocating church-state separation or science education.

3. Agnostic: Some atheists think of agnostic as a weenie term, because it gets used by people who lack a god-concept but dont want to offend family members or colleagues. Agnostic doesnt convey the same sense of confrontation or defiance that atheist can, and so it gets used as a bridge. But in reality, the term agnostic represents a range of intellectual positions that have important substance in their own right and can be independent of atheism. Strong agnosticism views Gods existence as unknowable, permanently and to all people. Weak agnosticism can mean simply I dont know if there is a God, or We collectively dont know if there is a God but we might find out in the future.

4. Skeptic: While agnostic focuses on God questions in particular, the term skeptic expresses a broader life approach. Someone who calls him- or herself a skeptic has put critical thinking at the heart of the matter. Skeptics, devote a majority of their effort to debunking pseudoscience, alternative medicine, astrology and so forth. They broadly challenge the human tendency to believe things on insufficient evidence. Australian comic Tim Minchen is an outspoken atheist who earns a living in part by poking fun at religion.

5. Freethinker: Free-thinker is a term that dates to the end of the 17th Century, when it was first used in England to describe those who opposed the Church and literal belief in the Bible. Freethought is an intellectual stance that says that opinions should be based on logic and evidence rather than authorities and traditions. The Freethinker, has been published in Britain continuously from 1881 to the present. The term has gotten popular recently in part because it is affirmative. Unlike atheism, which defines itself in contrast to religion, freethought identifies with a proactive process for deciding what is real and important.

6. Humanist: While terms like atheist or anti-theist focus on a lack of god-belief and agnostic, skeptic and freethinker all focus on ways of knowing humanist centers in on a set of ethical values. Humanism seeks to promote broad wellbeing by advancing compassion, equality, self-determination, and other values that allow individuals to flourish and to live in community with each other. These values drive not from revelation, but from human experience. Humanist leaders dont shy away from concepts like joy and inner peace that have spiritual connotations. In fact, some think that religion itself should be reclaimed by those who have moved beyond supernaturalism but recognize the benefits of spiritual community and ritual.

7. Pantheist: As self-described humanists seek to reclaim the ethical and communitarian aspects of religion, pantheists center in on the spiritual heart of faith, the experience of humility, wonder, and transcendence. They see human beings as one small part of a vast natural order, with the Cosmos itself made conscious in us. Pantheists reject the idea of a person- god, but believe that the holy is made manifest in all that exists. Consequently, they often have a strong commitment to protecting the sacred web of life in which and from which we have our existence.

Many people today describe themselves as spiritual but not religious, while others say they are not spiritual because they don't believe in spirits and other supernatural agents

Why aren't there any secular alternatives to Church?

The Sunday Assembly was started by Sanderson Jones and Pippa Evans, two comedians who were on the way to a gig in Bath when they discovered they both wanted to do something that was like church but totally secular and inclusive of allno matter what they believed.

The first ever Sunday Assembly meeting took place on January 6th 2013 at The Nave in Islington. Almost 200 people turned up at the first meeting, 300 at the second and soon people all over the world asked to start one.

Now there are over 70 Sunday Assembly chapters in 8 different countries where people sing songs, hear inspiring talks, and create community together.

Why do we exist? Life is short, it is brilliant, it is sometimes tough, we build communities that help everyone live life as fully as possible.

The only way to understand Sunday Assembly is to experience it for yourself. There will be singalong songs, moving stories, passionate speakersall finished with tea and cake (or coffee and doughnuts!).

They are the answer I was looking for when I wanted the community minus the supernatural (and they added pop songs and informative speakers!)

Why aren't there any famous temples of Agni Dev?

Because Agni is traditionally worshipped in Fire, just like Vayu is worshipped in prana etc. These Personalities of God are supposed to be honored and worshipped as a matter of duty more than as matter of bhakti. The tradition of temple worship is based on bhakti.

The ancient temples were dedicated mostly to Vishnu in his various forms, including Shiva mahadeva, and to the Mother Goddess in her various forms. Some temples, less in number, were dedicated to other two prominent Personalities of God, Surya and Ganesha. Other deities were considered primary or secondary manifestations of these main

Because Agni is traditionally worshipped in Fire, just like Vayu is worshipped in prana etc. These Personalities of God are supposed to be honored and worshipped as a matter of duty more than as matter of bhakti. The tradition of temple worship is based on bhakti.

The ancient temples were dedicated mostly to Vishnu in his various forms, including Shiva mahadeva, and to the Mother Goddess in her various forms. Some temples, less in number, were dedicated to other two prominent Personalities of God, Surya and Ganesha. Other deities were considered primary or secondary manifestations of these main Pancha devata, and worshipped locally or individually, meaning that any person could worship the particular aspect of the Divine Tattva that he felt more attracted to.

According to tradition, in satya and treta yuga there was no temple worship, because people attained perfect realisation by yoga and yajna respectively. Only in dvapara yuga temple worship was introduced, to help people meditate on God more easily, because yoga and yajna had become more difficult to practice. Bhakti is the most direct form of yoga and yajna: this is very clearly explained in Bhagavad gita.

Why is it called the church?

Church, by biblical definition, is the body of Christ (Christ, as the head). Another way to say it, though not necessarily Christian, is the body of believers. All and each individual of the particular belief. It is not, (as most people think) a building. Though many people refer to it as such....it isn't. The building can be any place that the church (the body) worships. The first worship structures were caves, tents, outside areas, and people's homes. Only much later, churches had buildings specifically designated for their get-togethers (fellowships; worship; pray/sing). Later, people, forgetting they each were a structural part of the body of believers, just referred to the building as, "the church". Unfortunately, many are, in a way......right. They didn't/don't look at themselves as an intricate part of the body of believers. They instead, designated THAT to be their building, instead.

Why aren't there more gnostic churches?

The fourth-century orthodox Christians made a real effort to wipe out all traces of Gnostic Christians until, by the fifth century, the Gnostics only survived in the more remote areas of the eastern Empire, where they were persecuted by Christians led by the Greek Orthodox Patriarch. Later, when the Muslim Turks conquered the Byzantine Empire, they permitted residents to remain Christians but required that they declare allegiance to the Patriarch. Rather than give their allegiance to the hated Orthodox Church, the Gnostic Christians in the region of Bosnia chose conversion to Islam.

Later in th

The fourth-century orthodox Christians made a real effort to wipe out all traces of Gnostic Christians until, by the fifth century, the Gnostics only survived in the more remote areas of the eastern Empire, where they were persecuted by Christians led by the Greek Orthodox Patriarch. Later, when the Muslim Turks conquered the Byzantine Empire, they permitted residents to remain Christians but required that they declare allegiance to the Patriarch. Rather than give their allegiance to the hated Orthodox Church, the Gnostic Christians in the region of Bosnia chose conversion to Islam.

Later in the Middle Ages, Gnostics reemerged as Cathars in southern France, northern Italy and parts of Spain. The Catholic Church launched the Albigensian Crusade and then the Medieval Inquisition to eliminate all traces of this heresy. Nothing was left standing that could remind people that there had ever been a Gnostic branch of Christianity.

What is the difference between a structure being considered a temple versus a church?

A church is a building dedicated to the worship of the Christian faith. A temple is a building that is dedicated to any of several other faiths including Buddhism, Judaism, and Hinduism and many others. Various traditions call their houses of worship different things and they all call their buildings different things.

Why are some churches called "mission" churches?

Usually this would be a larger church which would start off a smaller one in another part of the town or in a neighbouring village. As they would have taken full responsibility for initially starting the work, it was their mission in the missionary sense of the word. The intention would normally be to expect the Mission church to become self-supporting and independent in time, when it would probably lose the word Mission from its name

What is the meaning of a lukewarm church?

A church that is lukewarm is one that doesn't challenge, sharpen, or equip those who attend. This church hasnt become entirely cold towards God but neither do they burn with passion for Him. A lukewarm church has taken measures to make certain that spiritual comfort is more important than spiritual growth. This isn't simply a matter of bad teaching, rather its systemic; the events, programs, doctrine, worship, children's ministry, and leadership all have dulled the Word of God and the mission of the church to the extent that the church is end product instead of the people whom Jesus came to save. This manifests in a vast array of scenarios, (big churches, small churches, charismatic, baptist, etc) however each scenario is obvious in that you will notice that Jesus is not the head of this church, instead the pastor, a family, a movement, a program, or singular ideology has taken the throne of this church.

For Masjids;

It's hard to fit 50+ people into one room, in one home, with enough room to pray. Not to mention parking, space/safety limitations, and neighbors complaining.

Then there's also the idea to help out of town people. If they are traveling through it's probably harder to find a single home, but easy to find a masjid (due to sites and services like IslamicFinder and Zahbiah).

Now one thing I should comment on is the first part of your question:

why do we need to worship them in a specific place?

The short answer is we don't. In Islam a Masjid is simply a gathering place for likeminded individuals. There is nothing in the religion that says that Allah can only be worshiped there, actually it's quite the contrary. In Islam we must pray 5 times a day, every day. So it would be fairly hard for everyone to stop what they are doing and flock the the masjid at 5(ish), between 12-1pm, 3-4pm, 6-7pm, and 8-9pm, everyday. Instead we are allowed to pray and worship anywhere. I've prayed at my house, beside my desk at work, in a Christian Chapel, in a parking lot behind my car, in motel rooms, and many more places!
